desc: When a person is anxious, they worry that something bad will happen.
exam: She was anxious about not making her appointment on time.

desc: When something is awful, it is very bad.
exam: Her performance last night was awful.

desc: To consist of is to be made of parts or things.
exam: Today’s choices for lunch consisted of pizza, hamburgers, and hot dogs.

desc: To desire is to want something.
exam: My sister desires a big house and lots of money.

desc: When a person is eager about something, they are excited about it.
exam: The man was eager to talk about the good news.

desc: A household is all the people who live in one house.
exam: Our household is made up of my father, my mother and me.

desc: An intent is a plan to do something.
exam: Her intent is to visit Italy next summer.

desc: A landscape is how an area of land looks.
exam: The landscape of the country is very green.

desc: To lift something is to move it higher.
exam: The man tried to lift the box.

desc: To load is to put objects into something.
exam: The man loaded the boxes into a truck.

desc: A lung is the organ in the body that fills with air when breathing.
exam: Having strong lungs is necessary for a healthy life.

desc: A motion is a movement that someone makes.
exam: The police officer made a motion with his hand.

desc: The pace of something is the speed at which it happens.
exam: I ran the race at a slower pace than my friend.

desc: When someone is polite, they are acting in a thoughtful way.
exam: The boy was very polite: he behaved very thoughtfully.

desc: To possess something is to have it or own it.
exam: My uncle possesses three sheep, a chicken, a cow and a dog.

desc: When something happens rapidly, it happens very fast.
exam: The train moved rapidly on the tracks.

desc: To remark is to say something.
exam: The teacher remarked on how quickly the students were learning.

desc: To seek is to look for something.
exam: If I have a problem, I seek my sister’s advice.

desc: To shine is to make a bright light.
exam: The candles are shining in the dark room.

desc: To spill is to have something fall out of its container.
exam: I spilled the coffee on the table.

desc: To bring means to take someone or something to a person or place.
exam: Oscar will bring in all the boxes.

desc: A castle is a building with strong walls where royalty usually lives.
exam: The castle was built many years ago.

desc: To command someone is to tell them to do something.
exam: The general commanded his army to attack.

desc: To counsel someone is to listen and give advice about a problem.
exam: The teacher counseled the girl about her troubles.

desc: To ensure is to make certain that something happens.
exam: Eating good food ensures that we stay healthy.

desc: An explosion is a violent burst, usually with a loud sound.
exam: A nuclear explosion can cause great damage.

desc: Jewelry is something that people wear like earrings or necklaces.
exam: The woman looked beautiful with her nice dress and jewelry.

desc: To land means to come to the ground usually from a ship or aircraft.
exam: The parachutist landed safely on the ground.

desc: A meteor is a rock from outer space that falls to Earth.
exam: We saw a meteor in the sky last night.

desc: A monster is any imaginary frightening creature that looks strange.
exam: The monster scared everyone in the village.

desc: If something is northern, it is in the direction of north.
exam: It is much colder in northern countries than it is here.

desc: If something is remote, it is very far away and difficult to get to.
exam: It took many days to get to the remote island.

desc: If something is southern, it is in the direction of south.
exam: Taegu is located in the southern part of the Korean peninsula.

desc: A statue is an image of a person or animal made of stone or metal.
exam: I saw a beautiful statue of a lion today.

desc: Steam is water that has become hot and has turned into a misty gas.
exam: We could see the steam rise from the boiling water.

desc: To submit to someone is to agree to do what they tell you to do.
exam: She submitted to her mother’s wishes and did her homework.

desc: A temple is a building that is used for religious purposes.
exam: The people visited the temple to pray.

desc: Upper means higher in position or place.
exam: A home’s attic is at the upper part of the structure.

desc: A weed is a plant, especially one that is not useful or wanted.
exam: The yard of the house was full of ugly weeds.

desc: A wing is the part of an animal that lets it fly.
exam: The bird used its wings to fly across the water.

desc: An arrow is a thin, straight stick shot from a bow.
exam: The arrow flew through the air and hit the target.

desc: A battle is a fight between two armies during a war.
exam: The battle lasted for many days.

desc: A bow is a weapon made of curved wood and string that shoots arrows.
exam: He went hunting with a bow and arrow.

desc: When people are brave, they are not afraid to face pain or danger.
exam: The brave firefighter saved the girl from the burning building.

desc: A chief is the leader of a group of people.
exam: The chief led the people through the mountains.

desc: A disadvantage is a situation where someone is likely to lose.
exam: Mike had a disadvantage in the race since he hurt his knee.

desc: An enemy is a country that is fighting another country during a war.
exam: The enemy prepared to attack the kingdom.

desc: An entrance is a place where someone can enter an area.
exam: The gate was locked, so Bill had to find a different entrance.

desc: If something hardly happens, it almost does not happen at all.
exam: I hardly saw the concert since I had to leave early.

desc: To intend to do something means to plan to do it.
exam: I intend to finish college in three years.

desc: Laughter is the sound produced by laughing about something funny.
exam: Susan’s joke made her classmates burst into laughter.

desc: A log is a thick piece of wood that is cut from a tree.
exam: The fire was too small, so we added another log to it.

desc: The military is the armed forces of a country.
exam: I joined the military after I finished high school.

desc: To obey means to follow what a law or a person says you must do.
exam: My little sister did not obey my mother. Now she is in trouble.

desc: To secure something means to get it after a lot of effort.
exam: I was able to secure a good grade on my test after weeks of studying.

desc: When someone or something is steady, they are under control.
exam: The problem was hard but she remained steady and solved it.

desc: To trust is to believe that someone is honest and will do what is right.
exam: I trust my friends; they don’t tell my secrets to other people.

desc: To twist something is to wrap it around itself or another thing.
exam: She twisted the spaghetti around her fork.

desc: Unless means if not or except when.
exam: Unless you clean your room, you cannot play with your friends.

desc: A weapon is an object that can be used to hurt people.
exam: Swords have been used as weapons for thousands of years.

desc: The chest is the front part of a person’s body under the neck.
exam: The water in the lake was as high as my chest.

desc: If you have confidence about something, you are sure of it.
exam: I have confidence that I did well on the test.

desc: A consequence is a result of a choice or action.
exam: As a consequence of missing my bus, I had to find another way to work.

desc: A disaster is a really bad thing that happens.
exam: When the car crashed, it was a disaster.

desc: To disturb someone means to upset them.
exam: The loud noise disturbed me while I was working.

desc: To estimate something means to make a guess about it.
exam: The boy estimated that he was one meter tall.

desc: When you honor people or things, you show respect for them.
exam: I honor my science teacher by working hard in class.

desc: To impress someone means to make that person proud.
exam: He was able to impress the girls with his new dance.

desc: A marathon is a very long foot race just over 42 kilometers.
exam: I ran a marathon, and now my legs are tired.

desc: When something is narrow, it is very thin.
exam: The bridge is too narrow for a car to drive over.

desc: When something is pale, it does not have a bright color.
exam: The girl’s skin was very pale.

desc: When something is rough, it is not even or smooth.
exam: The rough ground hurt my feet.

desc: To satisfy someone means to make them happy.
exam: It will satisfy my teacher if I finish all my homework.

desc: To scream means to make a loud noise with your mouth.
exam: The girl saw a spider and screamed.

desc: When someone or something is sensitive, they are easily hurt.
exam: My teeth are sensitive to cold things.

desc: The shade is a dark area that something makes when it blocks the sun.
exam: It was hot outside, so the boy sat in the shade of a tree.

desc: To supplement something is to add something else to it in a good way.
exam: He supplements his diet with fresh fruits.

desc: When someone feels terror, they are scared.
exam: I felt a sense of terror when the tiger chased me.

desc: A threat is something bad that might happen.
exam: Due to the dark clouds, there was a threat of a bad storm.

desc: A victim is a person that had something bad happen to them.
exam: I was a victim of a robbery.

desc: An ancestor is a family member from the past.
exam: My ancestors came from Germany.

desc: An angle is the direction from which you look at something.
exam: The giraffe turned its head to see from another angle.

desc: A boot is a heavy shoe that goes over your ankle.
exam: He wore boots so that his feet wouldn’t get wet.

desc: A border is the edge of an area.
exam: The postcard had a pretty green border of pine needles.

desc: To congratulate someone is to tell them that you are happy for them.
exam: Bill and Angela congratulated each other on a job well done.

desc: A frame is a border for a picture or mirror.
exam: I have to get a frame for my friend’s picture.

desc: Heaven is the place that some people believe people go when they die.
exam: When I die, I hope that I go to heaven.

desc: If someone or something is incredible, it is hard to believe they are true.
exam: I have an incredible story to tell you about my vacation.

desc: A legend is a story from the past.
exam: There is a well-known legend about a king and his queen.

desc: To praise is to show that you like someone or something.
exam: The coach praised both athletes after a good practice.

desc: To proceed is to go in a certain direction.
exam: My son and I proceeded to the beach so we could go fishing.

desc: If something is pure, it is very clear and beautiful.
exam: The rose was pure. It had no dirt or imperfections.

desc: A relative is a family member.
exam: My relatives came by to see the new baby.

desc: If one is senior, they are the oldest or have been there the longest.
exam: Because he got his job first, Bob is the senior chef.

desc: If someone or something is silent, they make no sound.
exam: Since no one was home, the house was silent.

desc: To sink into something is to slowly fall into it.
exam: The boat had a hole in it, and it sank into the ocean.

desc: If someone or something is superior, they are better than another.
exam: I think cooking outdoors is superior to cooking indoors.

desc: To surround something is to close in on it from all sides.
exam: We surrounded the suspect on all four sides.

desc: If something is thick, it is wide and solid.
exam: The fog was so thick that I couldn’t see through it.

desc: To wrap is to cover something on all sides.
exam: I wrapped his gift and put a bow on it.

desc: If someone goes or travels abroad, they go to another country.
exam: My brother wants to go abroad next year.

desc: To anger someone is to make them mad.
exam: It angers me when people are rude.

desc: A bride is a woman who is getting married or has just gotten married.
exam: The bride looked beautiful in her wedding dress.

desc: If something is brief, it only lasts for a short time.
exam: The meeting this afternoon was very brief.

desc: To chase someone or something is to follow them in order to catch them.
exam: I was chased by an angry native.

desc: To disappoint is to make one feel sad or unsatisfied.
exam: I do not want to disappoint my family, so I try to do well at school.

desc: To dive is to jump into water.
exam: I will dive into the lake once we get there.

desc: To exchange means to give something for another thing in return.
exam: I exchanged my foreign money for American dollars.

desc: A favor is something you do for someone to help them.
exam: Can you do me a favor and turn off the lights?

desc: A fee is an amount of money that a person or company asks for a service.
exam: I had to pay an hourly fee to speak with my lawyer.

desc: If something lasts forever, it means it lasts for all time.
exam: The young couple promised that they would love each other forever.

desc: A guy is an informal way to call a man.
exam: The guy at the flower shop was really helpful today.

desc: If people or things are lovely, they are good-looking or beautiful.
exam: The trees look lovely in the fall.

desc: A mood is the way someone is feeling.
exam: I am in a good mood because I did well on my math test.

desc: A palace is a very large building. It is often the home of a royal family.
exam: The king and queen live in a beautiful palace.

desc: To permit something is to let someone do it.
exam: I was sick, so my mother permitted me to stay home from school.

desc: To protest something is to argue about it with someone.
exam: The people protested the decision of the president.

desc: A sculpture is a piece of art that is made from wood, clay, or stone.
exam: We saw an old sculpture of Buddha at the museum.

desc: A tribe is a group of people who live in the same culture.
exam: There’s a small tribe of people who live in the mountains of Spain.

desc: Youth is a time in people’s lives when they are young.
exam: My mother wanted to be a nurse in her youth.

desc: To do something on time’s basis is how often you do it.
exam: My grandfather gets his hearing checked on a yearly basis.

desc: Biology is the study of living things.
exam: We learned about the human heart in biology class.

desc: A cage is something that holds an animal so it cannot leave.
exam: We put the parrots in their cage at night.

desc: A colleague is somebody you work with.
exam: My colleague helped me finish the job.

desc: A colony is a country controlled by another country.
exam: The USA was at one time a colony of Great Britain.

desc: To debate is to seriously discuss something with someone.
exam: The husband and wife debated over which TV to buy.

desc: To depart is to leave some place so you can go to another place.
exam: The plane departed for Italy at 3:00 this afternoon.

desc: To depress someone is to make them sad.
exam: The bad news from work depressed the man.

desc: When something is factual, it is true.
exam: John learns about history from factual books.

desc: To fascinate someone is to make them really like something.
exam: The kitten was fascinated by the ball of yarn.
vi: hấp dẫn / cuốn hút / mê hoặc

desc: A mission is an important job that is sometimes far away.
exam: The woman’s mission was to help sick people.

desc: You use nevertheless to show that something goes against a fact.
exam: He is usually friendly. Nevertheless, he wasn’t this afternoon.

desc: An occupation is a person’s job.
exam: My father’s occupation is a dentist.

desc: If you go overseas, you go to a country on the other side of an ocean.
exam: John often goes overseas for vacations.

desc: To persuade someone is to make them agree to do something.
exam: The children persuaded their parents to buy them gifts.

desc: A route is the way you go from one place to another.
exam: I saw many new houses along the route to the city.

desc: Ruins are old buildings that are not used anymore.
exam: I visited some interesting ruins in Greece.

desc: A scholar is a person who studies something and knows much about it.
exam: The scholar knew much about art history.

desc: When someone or something is significant, they are important.
exam: I read many significant novels as a literature major in university.

desc: A volcano is a mountain with a hole on top where hot liquid comes out.
exam: When the volcano erupted, smoke and heat filled the air.

desc: If something is broad, it is wide.
exam: The river is very long and broad.

desc: A bush is a plant with many thin branches. It is smaller than a tree.
exam: My dad and I planted some small bushes around the house.

desc: If someone or something is capable of something, they can do it.
exam: The Olympic athlete is capable of lifting a lot of weight.

desc: To cheat is to be dishonest so that you can win or do well.
exam: They cheated on the test by sharing answers.

desc: To concentrate on someone or something is to give your full attention.
exam: I could not concentrate on my homework because the room was so loud.

desc: To conclude is to arrive at a logical end by looking at evidence.
exam: I saw crumbs on my dog’s face, so I concluded that he ate my cookie.

desc: Confident means that one believes they can do something without failing.
exam: She was confident she could climb the mountain due to her training.

desc: If something is considerable, it is large in size, amount or extent.
exam: They paid a considerable amount of money for that car.

desc: To convey is to communicate or make ideas known.
exam: That picture of a crying child conveys a feeling of sadness.

desc: If something is definite, it is certain or sure to be true.
exam: There is a definite connection between hard work and success.

desc: Delight is a feeling of being very happy with something.
exam: He felt such delight after getting a promotion at work.

desc: A destination is the place where someone or something is going to.
exam: The destination of this plane is Munich, Germany.

desc: To dictate something is to read it aloud so it can be written down.
exam: He dictated his speech so his secretary could write it down.

desc: The edge of something is the part of it that is farthest from the center.
exam: He ran to the edge of the cliff.

desc: A path is a way from one place to another that people can walk along.
exam: We followed a path through the woods.

desc: To resort to something is to depend on it in order to solve a problem.
exam: I hope they don’t resort to violence to end the argument.

desc: A shadow is the dark area that is made when something blocks light.
exam: The man’s shadow was taller than he was.

desc: To succeed is to complete something that you planned or tried to do.
exam: He will continue to work on the robot until he succeeds.

desc: To suspect something is to believe that it is true.
exam: I suspect that those kids stole the money.

desc: A valley is a low area of land between two mountains or hills.
exam: We looked at the valley below from the top of the mountain.

desc: To admire someone is to like them for what they do.
exam: I admire my brother for his hard work.

desc: To aid someone is to help them when they need something.
exam: The doctor aided the boy after his accident.

desc: To attempt something is to try to do that thing.
exam: I am attempting to learn English.

desc: Authority is the power that someone has because of their position.
exam: The policeman has authority on the streets.

desc: A capital is an important city where a country’s leaders live and work.
exam: We will visit the capital to learn about our government.

desc: To cooperate is to work together to do something.
exam: The students cooperated to clean up the classroom.

desc: To defend someone or something is to protect them from attack.
exam: The soldiers defended the town from the invaders.

desc: Destruction is damage to something so bad that it can’t be fixed.
exam: After the big fire, there was much destruction in the city.

desc: Disorder is a lack of order, or a complete mess.
exam: The teacher’s desk had many papers in disorder.

desc: A division is the act of making smaller groups out of a larger one.
exam: The chart had six divisions which all had different colors.

desc: To enable a person is to make it possible for them to do something.
exam: Having the key enabled us to open the door.

desc: To frustrate is to prevent someone from fulfilling their desire.
exam: The machine frustrated me because I could not fix it.

desc: To govern is to control the public business of a country, state, or city.
exam: The United States is governed from the White House.

desc: To have plenty of something is to have more than you need.
exam: The school had plenty of books for the students to read.

desc: To relieve someone is to make them feel less pain.
exam: The medicine relieved the sick boy.

desc: Reputation is the opinion that people have about someone.
exam: The doctor had a reputation for helping people.

desc: Royal describes something that belongs to a king or queen.
exam: The king sat upon the royal throne.

desc: A slave is a person who is not free and must work for someone else.
exam: The slave worked very hard all day long.

desc: To struggle is to fight against someone or something.
exam: The kids struggled with each other for the toy.

desc: When someone is stupid, they lack intelligence.
exam: He said something stupid that made everyone angry at him.

desc: A citizen is someone who lives in a certain town or city.
exam: Carlos was born in Spain. He is a Spanish citizen.

desc: A council is a group of people who run a city or town.
exam: The council met to discuss the new laws for the city.

desc: To declare is to say something officially.
exam: I declared my love for him.

desc: When people or things are enormous, they are very large.
exam: My dog looks enormous next to yours.

desc: When someone or something is extraordinary, they are amazing.
exam: The fireman who rescued the girl was extraordinary.

desc: Fog is a thick cloud that is near the ground or water.
exam: I did not want to drive in the thick fog.

desc: A funeral is a ceremony that takes place after a person dies.
exam: They had a funeral for the soldier who died during the war.

desc: When people or things are giant, they are very big.
exam: The giant truck got in my way.

desc: An impression is the way of thinking about someone or something.
exam: Most people’s first impression of Dr. Giani is that he is mean.

desc: Income is how much money a person or business makes.
exam: Her company pays her a fairly good income.

desc: When someone is mad, they are angry.
exam: Mother got mad when I didn’t listen to her.

desc: If someone ought to do something, then it is the right thing to do.
exam: I ought to take my library books back.

desc: To resist something is to fight against it.
exam: He resisted the treatment at the hospital.

desc: To reveal is to show something.
exam: I will reveal where I hid the candy bar.

desc: To rid is to make a place free from something or someone.
exam: We rid our home of mice by using traps.

desc: A sword is a long sharp weapon.
exam: They used to use swords in battles in ancient times.

desc: A tale is a story.
exam: She told her two friends about the wild tale of her day.

desc: To trap people or animals is to capture them so they cannot get away.
exam: We trapped butterflies in a net.

desc: A trial is the way a court discovers if a person is guilty or innocent.
exam: He went on trial for robbing the bank.

desc: When people are violent, they want to hurt someone.
exam: The man was put into jail because he was violent.

desc: Admission is the act of allowing to enter a place.
exam: The admission ticket to the movie was $5.

desc: Astronomy is the study of the stars and planets.
exam: Harold loved watching the stars, so he decided to study astronomy.

desc: To blame someone for something bad is to say they did it.
exam: My mom blamed me for something I didn’t do.

desc: Chemistry is the study of substances and their reactions.
exam: In chemistry class, the professor taught us about chemical reactions.

desc: If something happens despite what you do, it happens anyway.
exam: We still played the game despite the cold weather.

desc: A dinosaur is a very big animal that lived millions of years ago.
exam: I like to see the dinosaur bones at the museum.

desc: An exhibit is a display of interesting things.
exam: There was an animal exhibit at the fair.

desc: Fame is the reputation one has gained among the public.
exam: He had fame and fortune, but he was not happy.

desc: A forecast is an idea about what the weather will be like in the future.
exam: The forecast says that it will rain all week.

desc: A genius is a very smart person.
exam: Since she was a genius, she easily passed all of her school exams.

desc: Someone who is gentle is kind and calm.
exam: He is very gentle with the baby.

desc: Geography is the study of where things are.
exam: I had to draw a map for geography class.

desc: To interfere is to cause problems and keep something from happening.
exam: My little sister always interferes when I’m trying to study.

desc: To do something lightly is to not push very hard.
exam: Draw lightly so you do not tear your paper.

desc: A principal is a person in charge of a school.
exam: My school’s principal can be very strict with the rules.

desc: A row is a line of things.
exam: James put all of his toy soldiers into neat rows.

desc: A shelf is a place on a wall where you put things.
exam: I keep my clothes on a shelf in my closet.

desc: If you do something out of spite, you want to be mean.
exam: He snuck into his sister’s room and stole her bag out of spite.
vi: thù hằn / ác cảm / bất chấp

desc: Super means really good.
exam: My dad said I did a super job cleaning the house.

desc: If something is wet, it has water on it.
exam: Since my dog was wet, he tried to shake all the water off his body.

desc: To abuse someone or something means to hurt them on purpose.
exam: The mean man abused his dog when it barked too loudly.

desc: To afford something means you have enough money to pay for it.
exam: I’ve been saving my money, so I can afford to buy a new bike.

desc: To bake means to cook food with heat.
exam: My sister is a good cook. She bakes delicious cakes.

desc: A bean is a plant seed that is good to eat.
exam: There are many different kinds of beans to eat.

desc: A candle is a stick of wax that is lit on fire for light or heat.
exam: When the lights went out, we lit some candles.

desc: To convert something means to change it into something else.
exam: The man converted his messy field into a garden of flowers.

desc: A debt is an amount of money that a person owes.
exam: I have not paid my gas bill. I owe a debt to the gas company.

desc: To decrease something is to make it less than it was before.
exam: Hiring more police officers has decreased crime in the city.

desc: A fault is a mistake.
exam: It is my fault that the cat ran away. I left the door open.

desc: A fund is an amount of money that people have.
exam: We all put money into our club’s fund.

desc: When someone is generous, they like to give things to people.
exam: The generous man donated several new computers to our school.

desc: An ingredient is something that is part of a food dish.
exam: The main ingredients in cake are eggs, sugar and flour.

desc: To insist means to be firm in telling people what to do.
exam: I insist that you try some of these cookies.

desc: A mess is a condition that is not clean or neat.
exam: Heather’s room was a complete mess.

desc: Metal is a strong material people use to build things.
exam: Steel is a common metal that is used to build buildings.

desc: To monitor people or things is to watch them closely.
exam: The teacher monitors the students when they take tests.

desc: To oppose something means to dislike it or act against it.
exam: I want to be a police officer because I oppose crime.

desc: If a person is passive, they do not take action to solve problems.
exam: Marcie is so passive that she never solves her own problems.

desc: A quantity is a certain amount of something.
exam: I have a small quantity of milk in my glass.

desc: To sue someone is to take them to court for something wrong they did.
exam: I sued the company after I slipped on a banana peel in their hallway.

desc: When someone has anxiety, they have a lot of worries and fear.
exam: When I have to climb to high places, I’m filled with anxiety.

desc: An army is a large group of people who fight in wars.
exam: The army protects all the people in the country.

desc: A billion is a very large number: 1,000,000,000.
exam: There are billions of stars in outer space.

desc: To carve means to cut into something.
exam: My father usually carves the turkey for Thanksgiving.

desc: To consult someone means to ask them for help.
exam: I will consult my accountant to find a way to pay for my bills.

desc: An emergency is a time when someone needs help right away.
exam: There is a huge fire in my house! This is an emergency!

desc: When someone has good fortune, it means they have luck.
exam: I have good fortune when I play cards.

desc: To guarantee means to know something will happen.
exam: I guarantee that the sun will come up in the morning.

desc: To hike means to walk in the mountains or forest.
exam: I always bring plenty of equipment with me when I hike.

desc: When something is initial, it is the first thing.
exam: The initial step when writing a paper is to find a good topic.

desc: If something is intense, it is very strong.
exam: The skunk made an intense odor that filled the air.

desc: To lend something is to give it to someone for a short time.
exam: My sister lost her pen, so I will lend her mine.

desc: The peak is the very top of a mountain.
exam: There is snow on the peaks of those mountains.

desc: Potential means capable of being but not yet in existence.
exam: I’ve thought of some potential problems with your idea.

desc: When you have pride, you are happy with yourself.
exam: I take pride in getting good grades.

desc: Proof is a fact that shows something is real.
exam: They used his fingerprint as proof for the crime he committed.

desc: To quit something means to stop doing it.
exam: I quit running because I got tired.

desc: To spin is to turn around in circles.
exam: The boy kept spinning until he fell down.

desc: When people or things are tiny, they are very small.
exam: A baby’s hand is tiny.

desc: A tutor is someone who gives lessons in a certain subject.
exam: My sister is bad at math. So my mother hired a tutor to help her.

desc: If something is apparent, it is easy to see.
exam: Her happiness was apparent from the smile on her face.

desc: When people are blind, they cannot see.
exam: The blind man didn’t see the hole and almost fell in.

desc: To calculate is to find an answer using math.
exam: I calculated how much money I would need to buy the car.

desc: To chat is to talk with someone.
exam: Even though they were far apart, the couple chatted every day.

desc: To commit to something is to promise to do it.
exam: Seth wanted to go home, but he had committed to finishing the job.

desc: To compose something is to make it from smaller parts.
exam: Tonya composed her report using many sources of information.

desc: A dormitory is a school building where students live.
exam: I will move into the dormitory at the beginning of the school year.

desc: To exhaust someone is to make them tired.
exam: John exhausted himself by swimming all day.

desc: A greenhouse is a small glass building that is used to grow plants.
exam: We have a small greenhouse in our backyard where we grow plants.

desc: To ignore something is to act like you do not see or hear it.
exam: I ignored the message he was making and kept studying.

desc: If something is obvious, it is clear and easily seen.
exam: It was obvious that he was tired. He kept falling asleep.

desc: Physics is a science that deals with energy and how it affects things.
exam: In physics class, we used Newton’s Cradle to learn about energy.

desc: A portion of something is a part of it.
exam: I only ate a small portion of the pizza.

desc: To remind someone is to tell them to remember to do something.
exam: Nick’s dad reminded him to do his homework.

desc: A secretary is a person who works in an office.
exam: Rebecca asked her secretary to type a report.

desc: If something is severe, it is very bad or serious.
exam: After hitting his hand with the hammer, Sam was in severe pain.

desc: If someone has a talent, they are naturally able to do it well.
exam: Maria has a talent for playing the piano.

desc: A thesis is an idea that needs to be proved.
exam: She did not support her thesis very well.

desc: A uniform is a piece of clothing worn by people of the same group.
exam: All the members of our marching band wear matching uniforms.

desc: Vision is the act of seeing.
exam: The eye doctor tested my vision.

desc: To absorb a liquid means to take it inside.
exam: He used a sponge to absorb the water on the floor.

desc: A boss is a person in charge of other people at work.
exam: My boss is a nice person.

desc: A committee is a group of people who meet together to make decisions.
exam: The school’s committee agreed on a new dress code for students.

desc: A contract is a written agreement between two people.
exam: The woman signed a contract when she bought the house.

desc: A crew is a group of workers.
exam: My father has a crew. They help him build houses.

desc: To devote time to something means to spend a lot of time doing it.
exam: She devotes two hours a day to playing the piano.

desc: To dig is to make a hole in the ground.
exam: My dog digs in the yard so he can hide his bones.

desc: To dine means to eat dinner.
exam: The young couple dined at their home.

desc: To donate is to give something to a charity or organization.
exam: We donate money to Christmas charities every year.

desc: If something is double, it is twice as much, or twice as many.
exam: I paid almost double the amount for that shirt.

desc: To elevate something is to put it at a higher level.
exam: The man elevated the picture so he could see it better.

desc: A flavor is the taste of food or drinks.
exam: The flavor of the ice cream was very good.

desc: A foundation is a group that provides money for research.
exam: The foundation raised money to give scholarships to students.

desc: A generation is a group of people who live at the same time.
exam: My grandparents are from a different generation than me.

desc: A handle is the part of an object people hold while using it.
exam: The pot is very hot. So pick it up by the handle.

desc: A layer covers over something or is between two things.
exam: There was a layer of snow on the tops of the houses this morning.

desc: Mud is soft, wet dirt.
exam: My brother played rugby in the mud. Now he’s dirty.

desc: If something is smooth, it has no bumps.
exam: The baby’s skin felt very smooth.

desc: Soil is the top layer of land on the Earth.
exam: The boy planted flowers in the soil and watered them every day.

desc: If people or things are unique, they are not like the others.
exam: Her dog is unique. I’ve never seen one quite like it.
vi: độc đáo / độc nhất / duy nhất

desc: A chamber is an old word for a bedroom.
exam: The girl was tired. She went to her chamber fora nap.

desc: To deny something is to say it is not true.
exam: The boy denied that he broke the window.

desc: A document is an official piece of writing.
exam: He was given an official document proving he was a citizen.

desc: To emphasize is to give importance or attention to something.
exam: She emphasized the key points by circling them in red ink.

desc: A fever is a high body temperature that people get when they are sick.
exam: Lydia had a high fever so she didn’t go to school.

desc: The flu is a type of sickness that makes you feel weak or your body hurt.
exam: Since he had the flu, he felt miserable.

desc: To freeze is to become very cold.
exam: If you don’t wear your coat in winter, you will freeze.

desc: A gesture is a movement of the hands or body.
exam: My teacher makes a lot of gestures when she speaks.

desc: To interrupt is to briefly stop someone when they are doing something.
exam: My mother interrupted me when I was trying to listen to music.

desc: To last is to continue or go on for an amount of time.
exam: The football match lasted for nearly two hours.

desc: Likeness means the state of being like, or resemblance.
exam: Michelle bears a strong likeness to her older sister Kate.

desc: Moreover means besides or in addition to something.
exam: It’s cold outside. Moreover, the wind is very strong.

desc: A perspective is the way you think about something.
exam: The man’s speech gave me a new perspective on our country.

desc: When something is rational, it is normal or practical.
exam: It is hard to think in a rational way when you are scared.

desc: To recover is to go back to normal after something bad happens.
exam: I hope the city will recover soon after the flood.

desc: To rely on something or someone is to trust or depend on them.
exam: The boy relied on his older brother to help him.

desc: To shock people is to surprise them.
exam: The man was shocked by the news.

desc: When people are shy, they are nervous around people strange to them.
exam: The girl was too shy to try out for the play.

desc: To stare at something is to look at it for a long time.
exam: The young couple stared into each other’s eyes.

desc: Thus means as a result or for that reason.
exam: The sun was shining. Thus, I wore my sunglasses.

desc: An aim is a goal someone wants to make happen.
exam: My aim is to become a helicopter pilot.

desc: To attach is to put two things together.
exam: I attached the socks to the clothesline to dry.

desc: To bet is to risk money on the result of a game or a business.
exam: How much will you bet that your horse will win?

desc: A carriage is a vehicle pulled by a horse.
exam: We took a carriage ride in the park.

desc: If something is classic, it is typical.
exam: The athlete made a classic mistake-he started running too soon.
vi: đặc trưng /  kinh điển / điển hình

desc: To commute is to travel a long distance to get to work.
exam: I usually commute to work on the train.

desc: To confirm is to make sure something is correct.
exam: Winning the game confirmed that James was a good player.

desc: To criticize is to say you do not like someone or something.
exam: He criticized his wife for spending too much money.

desc: To differ is to not be the same as another person or thing.
exam: I differ from my brother: he is short, while I am tall.

desc: An expense is the money that people spend on something.
exam: She wrote down all the expenses for her trip.

desc: If something is formal, it is done in an official way.
exam: It was a formal dinner, so we wore our best clothes.

desc: Height is how tall someone or something is.
exam: My height is 168 centimeters.

desc: To invent something is to create something that never existed before.
exam: My grandfather has invented some interesting things.

desc: If someone is junior in their job, they do not have a lot of power.
exam: When she started at the company, she was only a junior manager.
vi: cấp thấp / mới có kinh nghiệm

desc: Labor is the act of doing or making something.
exam: Building the house took a lot of labor.

desc: A mechanic is someone who fixes vehicles or machines.
exam: We took the car to the mechanic to be fixed.

desc: If something is prime, it is the most important one.
exam: Dirty air is a prime cause of illness.

desc: To shift to something is to move into a new place or direction.
exam: He shifted to the other side of the table to eat his breakfast.

desc: A signal is a sound or action that tells someone to do something.
exam: The coach blew his whistle as a signal to begin the game.

desc: When people are sincere, they tell the truth.
exam: He sounded sincere when he apologized to me.

desc: Ability is the quality of a person being able to do something well.
exam: His swimming abilities let him cross the entire lake.

desc: Agriculture is the growing of food and animals.
exam: The farmer studied agriculture in college.

desc: A cartoon is a funny drawing.
exam: Sometimes, people draw cartoons for the newspaper.

desc: The ceiling is the top of a room.
exam: He painted the ceiling with a special roller.

desc: To convince someone means to make them sure of something.
exam: She convinced me to buy the house.

desc: When you are curious about something, you want to know more about it.
exam: I opened up the clock because I was curious about how it worked.

desc: To delay means to wait to do something.
exam: I was delayed at the airport for over two hours.

desc: A diary is a book in which people write their personal experiences.
exam: I do not let anybody read my diary.

desc: An element of something is a particular part of it.
exam: Tackling an opponent is Johnny’s favorite element of American footbal.

desc: When people have faith in something, they believe in it and trust it.
exam: The sick girl had faith in doctors. She knew they would make her better.

desc: Grain is food crops such as wheat, corn, rice or oats.
exam: The farmer planted two fields of grain this year.

desc: To greet someone means to meet and welcome them.
exam: When my friend came over, I greeted him at the door.

desc: To investigate means to search for something or learn about it.
exam: The detective went to investigate the crime.

desc: Joy is a feeling you get when you are really happy.
exam: I love baseball. I feel joy when I play.

desc: A label is a tag that tells about something.
exam: The label on the back of your shirt will tell you what size it is.

desc: A monk is a religious person who lives a simple life.
exam: The monks knew a lot about religion.

desc: When something is odd, it is unusual.
exam: Her cat is odd. It walks on two feet.

desc: To pause means to stop doing something for a while.
exam: Since she was so hungry, she paused to make a snack.

desc: A priest is a person trained to perform religious duties.
exam: The priest taught us about God.

desc: A profession is a person’s job.
exam: He loved sailing, so he chose to work on ships as a profession.

desc: To adopt someone is to make them as a part of one’s own family.
exam: The girl was adopted by the couple when she was three.

desc: To beg is to ask for something one really wants.
exam: The man begged for some money.

desc: If A is beyond B, A is farther away.
exam: John’s house is beyond that lake.

desc: A costume is a set of clothes people wear for a particular occasion.
exam: The woman wore a mask with her costume.

desc: To exclaim is to say something loudly, usually due to being excited.
exam: “Look at her dress!” Sara exclaimed.

desc: To extend is to stretch out or reach.
exam: The boy extended his hand to catch the ball.

desc: A fool is someone who makes unwise choices.
exam: The girl was a fool for playing too close to the water.

desc: To forbid is to tell someone they cannot do something.
exam: My father forbids watching TV while we’re eating dinner.

desc: To illustrate is to show something by drawing a picture.
exam: The executive illustrated the decreasing profits of the company.

desc: Indeed means truly or really.
exam: The birthday party was indeed fun last night.

desc: To interpret is to explain what something means.
exam: The woman interpreted what her co-worker was trying to say.

desc: If people do something kindly, they do it in a nice way.
exam: The stranger kindly cared for the hurt man.

desc: A motive is the reason someone does something.
exam: His motive for studying so hard is to get into a good college.

desc: A nest is a place where a bird lays its eggs.
exam: The bird laid her eggs in the nest that she made.

desc: The origin of someone or something is where they come from.
exam: The origin of the honey that we eat is from a beehive.

desc: A reception is a party to welcome a person or celebrate an event.
exam: We all danced and had a good time at the wedding reception.

desc: To reject is to refuse something because you do not want it.
exam: The girl rejected the broken cup.

desc: Silence is complete quiet.
exam: The man asked for silence while he worked on the problem.

desc: A stream is a small river.
exam: The boy caught a fish in the stream.

desc: Tone is the sound of someone’s voice. It shows how they feel.
exam: My father’s tone told me I had broken the rule.

desc: To accomplish something means to finish it.
exam: He accomplished his goal of running ten miles.

desc: To approve of something means you like it or are happy about it.
exam: Her co-workers approved her new plan.

desc: Approximate means to be close to an exact amount, number or time.
exam: My approximate height is two meters.

desc: A barrier is something that is in your way.
exam: The Great Wall was a barrier between China and its enemies.

desc: To detect something means to notice or find something.
exam: The boy ran to the kitchen when he detected the smell of cookies.

desc: A duty is something that a person has to do.
exam: It is parents’ duty to take care of their children.

desc: When something is elementary, it is the first or most simple thing.
exam: Children go to elementary school before high school.

desc: A failure happens when you do not do something right.
exam: My cooking ended in failure because I burned the food.

desc: When something is gradual, it happens slowly.
exam: Children learn to read at a gradual pace. They do not learn right away.

desc: An immigrant is a person who moves to a different country.
exam: My parents were immigrants. They came from Poland.

desc: To insert something means to put it in something else.
exam: The mailman inserted the letter into the mailbox.

desc: An instant is a very short amount of time.
exam: A microwave oven cooks food in an instant.

desc: Poverty is the state of being poor.
exam: Poverty is a problem in many countries around the world.

desc: To pretend means to make believe something is real.
exam: The boy liked to pretend he was a king.

desc: A person’s rank is their place in an order of people.
exam: The man got to the rank of captain in the navy.

desc: Recognition is getting praise from other people.
exam: The hero got recognition for his brave deed.

desc: To refrigerate something means to make it cold.
exam: Grocery stores refrigerate fruit to make it last long.

desc: Rent is the money people pay to someone to live in a certain place.
exam: To live in this house, I have to pay rent at the start of each month.

desc: To retire is to leave a job, usually because of old age.
exam: My father is sixty-five years old. He is about to retire from work.

desc: A statistic is a number that tells a fact about something.
exam: The statistics showed that we did just as well this year as last year.

desc: An astronaut is a person that goes into outer space.
exam: The astronaut was walking on the moon.

desc: When you are awake, you are not asleep.
exam: Sometimes I lay awake in bed because I am not tired.

desc: When you have courage, you are not afraid.
exam: The man had the courage to touch the lion.

desc: To float is to move on top of water without sinking.
exam: The boy’s toy boat floated in the pool.

desc: To grant something is to allow someone to have it.
exam: The teacher granted us a break after studying hard all day.

desc: Gravity is the force that makes things fall to Earth.
exam: There is no gravity in space.

desc: A jewel is a beautiful stone that is worth a lot of money.
exam: A diamond is one of the most expensive jewels in the world.

desc: A miner is a person who works in a mine.
exam: The miner was looking for gold.

desc: A mineral is a type of substance found in the Earth.
exam: Rocks are made up of different kinds of minerals.

desc: To participate is to take part in something.
exam: The students participated in the school play.

desc: Permission means the act of allowing the doing of something.
exam: I have permission to drive my mom’s car.

desc: To pour a liquid means to make it come out of a container.
exam: I poured some milk into my sister’s cup.

desc: Someone or something’s presence is the fact they are there.
exam: The presence of dark clouds meant it would rain.

desc: If a material is raw, it is natural and has not been processed.
exam: The company dumped raw sewage into the river.

desc: A satellite is something that is sent into space to get information.
exam: The satellite was traveling around the earth.

desc: The scale of something is its size, especially when it is very large.
exam: I was surprised by the scale of the buildings in the downtown area.

desc: To skip something is to not do it.
exam: He skipped work to get more sleep.

desc: To stretch is to make your arms or legs reach out.
exam: She stretched her body before exercising.

desc: A telescope is a tool people use to look at the stars.
exam: With a telescope, you can see the moon and stars easily.
vi: kính thiên văn / kính viễn vọng

desc: When something is underground, it is below the surface of the Earth.
exam: Subway trains travel underground.

desc: An alarm is something that warns people of danger.
exam: When the students heard the fire alarm, they left the building.

desc: When people or things are apart, they are not close together.
exam: The couple decided to live apart from each other.

desc: To arrest someone means to catch them for doing something bad.
exam: The man was arrested for breaking the law.

desc: An award is a prize someone gets for doing something well.
exam: He got an award for having the best grades in class.

desc: A breed is a group of animals within a species.
exam: I like small dog breeds, such as terriers.

desc: A bucket is a round container to put things in.
exam: I filled the bucket with water.

desc: A contest is a game or a race.
exam: The girls had a contest to see who could jump higher.

desc: To convict someone means to prove that they did a bad thing.
exam: He was convicted of the crime and sent to jail.

desc: A garage is the part of a house where people put their cars.
exam: My car does not get dirty because I keep it in the garage.

desc: A journalist is a person who writes news stories.
exam: The journalist took notes for a story he was writing.

desc: A pup is a young dog.
exam: All the girl wanted for her birthday was a pup.

desc: To qualify is to get, or to be declared, adequate or good enough.
exam: He qualified to go to the final match by beating the opponent.
vi: đạt yêu cầu / đủ điều kiện

desc: To repair something is to fix it.
exam: I repaired the flat tire on my car.

desc: To resume something means to start it again after taking a break.
exam: I put the newspaper down to eat breakfast. Then I resumed reading.

desc: To rob a person or place is to take their property by using force.
exam: A thief has robbed me of my passport.

desc: To slip means to slide and fall down.
exam: The man slipped on the wet floor.

desc: Somewhat means to some degree, but not to a large degree.
exam: James was somewhat upset when he had to move some boxes.

desc: When something is stable, it will not fall over.
exam: The chair is stable. Its legs are strong.

desc: A tissue is a soft piece of paper people use to wipe their noses.
exam: There was a box of tissue on the table.

desc: A yard is the ground just outside of a person’s house.
exam: The girls jumped rope in the yard.

desc: If two things or people are alike, they are similar in some way.
exam: People often think my sister and I look alike.

desc: To annoy someone means to bother them.
exam: The flies buzzing around John’s head annoyed him very much.

desc: Architecture is the style or way a building is made.
exam: The architecture of the church is amazing.

desc: If something is artificial, it is made to look like something natural.
exam: That soccer field has artificial grass, but it looks real.

desc: A chain is a series of connected loops often used to keep things in place.
exam: The scary dog was secured with a chain.

desc: If something is distinct, it is easily noticed or different from other things.
exam: That girl has distinct pink hair.

desc: To distinguish is to recognize differences between things.
exam: The twins look exactly the same. It is hard to distinguish between them.

desc: Dust is very tiny pieces of dirt or other matter.
exam: In the old house, the dust was thick on the floor and chairs.

desc: Excitement means to feel a lot of happiness about something.
exam: Did you see the excitement in her when the team scored?

desc: To heal means to make a part of the body healthy again after injury.
exam: After my broken arm heals, I can play baseball again.

desc: To inherit is to get something from someone who has died.
exam: She inherited her mother’s gold earrings.

desc: A manner is the way someone does something.
exam: His manner of not looking at someone while speaking, is a bit rude.

desc: Something mounts when it becomes stronger over time.
exam: His fear mounted as the monster crawled out from under his bed.

desc: A roof is the outside top part of a building.
exam: The roof was covered with snow.

desc: A shortage is a lack of something you need or want.
exam: Since there was a shortage of food, people were hungry.

desc: If something is solid, it is made of firm material.
exam: The safe looked to be quite solid.

desc: A stock is a stored amount of something.
exam: They keep a stock of rice so they’ll always have something to eat.

desc: A substance is any specific material or mixture of materials.
exam: Water is an important substance for all living things.

desc: A tomb is a grave where a dead person is buried.
exam: Their whole family is buried inside the tomb.

desc: A wound is an injury to the body.
exam: He had many wounds after the car accident.

desc: A bath is water in a tub. People take a bath to get clean.
exam: After playing in the dirt, the boy took a bath.

desc: To bend is to move something so it is not straight.
exam: Lee bent over and picked up the paper on the ground.

desc: To chew is to move your mouth to break up food.
exam: I always chew my food carefully before swallowing it.

desc: When a person is disabled, they cannot do what a normal person can do.
exam: The disabled man used a wheelchair to move around.

desc: If something is fantastic, it is really good.
exam: The student did a fantastic job on his project and got an award.

desc: Fiction is a story that is not true.
exam: I enjoy reading works of fiction because they are very entertaining.

desc: A flag is a piece of colored cloth that represents something.
exam: Our country has a beautiful flag.

desc: To inspect is to look at something carefully.
exam: The mechanic inspected our car to see if it had any problems.

desc: A journal is a type of magazine that deals with an academic subject.
exam: Mi-young was busy working on an article for an art journal.

desc: A liquid is a substance that is neither solid nor gas.
exam: Water is the most important liquid for life.

desc: To marvel at something is to feel surprise and interest in it.
exam: We marveled at her excellent piano playing.

desc: A nutrient is something that a living thing needs to keep it alive.
exam: Vegetables are full of important nutrients.

desc: To overcome a problem is to successfully fix it.
exam: She overcame her shyness and spoke in front of the class.

desc: To recall something is to remember it.
exam: She was trying to recall what she had told her friend.

desc: To regret something is to wish that it didn’t happen.
exam: I regret that I was mean to my sister.

desc: A soul is a person’s spirit.
exam: Some people believe that the soul lives after the body dies.

desc: When something is sufficient, you have enough of it.
exam: After eating a sufficient amount of food, I left the table.

desc: Surgery is medical treatment when the doctor cuts open your body.
exam: I needed surgery to repair my leg after the accident.

desc: If something is tough, it is difficult.
exam: The man passed his driving test even though it was very tough.

desc: A tube is a pipe through which water or air passes.
exam: The pile of tubes was going to be put in the ground.

desc: To admit something means to say that it is true.
exam: I had to admit that I stole his idea.

desc: A bin is a container that holds things.
exam: He put his trash in the bin.

desc: A bowl is a deep, round dish that holds food or liquid.
exam: I ate a bowl of cereal for breakfast.

desc: A cabin is a small house made of wood.
exam: My grandfather owns a small cabin in the country.

desc: Cash is money in the form of paper or coins.
exam: I was able to save up enough cash to buy my mother a gift.

desc: A criminal is a person who does something against the law.
exam: The police made sure the criminal couldn’t move his hands.

desc: A dozen is a group of twelve things.
exam: Mom brought home a dozen donuts for us as a treat.

desc: An elder is a person who is older than the people around them.
exam: Uncle Ray is my elder so I always try to be respectful.

desc: If something is facial, it is related to a person’s face.
exam: I could tell from his facial features that he was angry.

desc: A fence is a structure around a house or field.
exam: The farmer put up a fence so that no one could walk on her field.

desc: To inspire means to make a person want to do something.
exam: I was inspired to write a poem after watching the sunrise.

desc: When something is mere, it is small or not important.
exam: We lost the game by a mere two points.

desc: If something is neat, it is very clean or organized well.
exam: My sister always keeps her bedroom very neat.

desc: An occasion is a time when something important happens.
exam: Her graduation was an occasion to have a good time.

desc: A penalty is a punishment, given when someone breaks a rule or law.
exam: I had to pay a $100 penalty for parking in the wrong spot.

desc: When someone is rude, they are mean and not polite.
exam: The children at the bus stop were very rude.

desc: To settle a problem means to end it by finding a solution.
exam: It took three of our best executives all day to settle the problem.

desc: A vehicle is a thing that moves people or things to another place.
exam: A ferry is a vehicle that takes people from one island to another.

desc: A wallet is a thing that holds money and fits in a pocket.
exam: I keep my money in a wallet.

desc: To yell is to say something very loudly.
exam: The coach yelled at his team for their poor performance.

desc: To accuse someone of something is to blame them for doing it.
exam: She accused her brother of breaking her computer.

desc: To adjust something means to change it so it is better.
exam: He adjusted the old guitar to make it sound better.

desc: To amuse someone means to do something that is funny or entertaining.
exam: The singer was very good. She amused the crowd.

desc: Coral is the hard, colorful material formed by the shells of animals.
exam: The diver admired the beautiful coral under the water.

desc: Cotton is a cloth made from the fibers of the cotton plant.
exam: I like to wear clothes made from cotton in the summer.

desc: To crash means to hit and break something.
exam: There was a loud noise when the car crashed into the tree.

desc: A deck is a wooden floor built outside of a house or the floor of a ship.
exam: A ship will store many supplies below its deck.

desc: To engage in something means to do it.
exam: Dad was engaged in sawing a piece of wood in half.

desc: When something is firm, it is solid but not too hard.
exam: He sleeps better on a firm bed.

desc: Fuel is something that creates heat or energy.
exam: Heat is the fuel that comes from fire.

desc: When something is grand, it is big and liked by people.
exam: The grand mountain rose high into the sky.

desc: A hurricane is a bad storm that happens over the ocean.
exam: The wind from the hurricane bent the palm tree.

desc: A loss means the act or an instance of losing something.
exam: I suffered a big loss while I was gambling.

desc: If something is simple, it is plain and not decorated.
exam: He bought a pair of plain white shoes over the weekend.

desc: A reef is a group of rocks or coral that rise to or near the ocean.
exam: He walked along the reef and looked at the water below.

desc: To shut something means to close it tightly.
exam: Please shut the door; the air outside is cold.

desc: When someone is strict, they make sure others follow rules.
exam: The teacher is strict. She does not let students talk in class.

desc: To surf means to use a special board to ride on waves in the ocean.
exam: The students went to the beach to surf during their vacation.

desc: A task is a piece of work to be done that is usually difficult.
exam: My task for the weekend was to clean the entire back yard.

desc: A zone is an area that has different qualities from the ones around it.
exam: Firefighters often work in danger zones.

desc: An apology is something someone says to show that they are sorry.
exam: After arguing with her teacher, the girl wrote the teacher an apology.

desc: If someone is bold, they are not afraid of doing something.
exam: The bold man climbed the high mountain.

desc: To capture someone or something is to catch them.
exam: James tried to capture the bubbles in his hands.

desc: If a rule or quality is cardinal, then it is the most important one.
exam: Raising your hand in the classroom before you speak is a cardinal rule.

desc: A duke is a man of high social rank but below a king or queen.
exam: The duke ruled over the land.

desc: To expose is to make known something that is hidden.
exam: He took off his shirt exposing his costume.

desc: If people feel guilty, they feel bad for what they did.
exam: I felt guilty for taking my sister’s cookies.

desc: To hire someone is to pay them money to work for you.
exam: We hired a man to paint our house.

desc: If someone is innocent, they are not guilty of a crime.
exam: The judge said that the woman was innocent of the crime.

desc: Jail is a place where criminals go to be punished.
exam: The thief was caught and sent to jail for ten years.

desc: A minister is an important person in government with many duties.
exam: The minister of education controls the country’s schools.

desc: If someone or something is ordinary, they are not special in any way.
exam: Today was just an ordinary day. Nothing unusual happened.

desc: If something is permanent, it lasts for a long time or forever.
exam: We don’t know if Aunt Mildred’s visit will be a permanent one.

desc: To preserve is to protect something from harm.
exam: Dad sprayed a chemical on the house to help preserve its looks.

desc: To pronounce is to say the sounds of letters or words.
exam: Young children often have trouble pronouncing words right.

desc: To resemble someone is to look like them.
exam: The baby resembles his father a great deal.

desc: A symptom of a bad condition or illness is a sign that it is happening.
exam: Sneezing and a high fever are symptoms of the common cold.

desc: Tobacco is a plant whose leaves are smoked, such as in cigarettes.
exam: The tobacco in cigarettes is bad for your health.

desc: Twins are two children born at the same time.
exam: My sister and I are twins. We look exactly the same.

desc: A witch is a woman with magical powers.
exam: People think that witches fly around on broomsticks.

desc: To accompany other people means to join them or go with them.
exam: My brothers accompanied me to the movie.

desc: When something is bare, it is plain. It has no covering.
exam: He likes to walk around in his bare feet.

desc: A branch is the part of a tree with leaves.
exam: The monkey was hanging from a branch on the tree.

desc: A breath is the air that goes into and out of one’s lungs.
exam: You can’t take a breath under water.

desc: A bridge is something that is built over a river so people can cross it.
exam: The old bridge fell into the river.

desc: To cast something means to throw it.
exam: The fisherman cast his line into the water.

desc: To dare means to be brave enough to try something.
exam: He dared to jump out of the airplane and skydive.

desc: When something is electronic, it uses electricity to do something.
exam: I like having electronic devices such as an MP3 player.

desc: An inn is a place where travelers can rest and eat.
exam: The visitor got a room at the inn.

desc: A net is a bag made of strong thread. It is used to catch animals.
exam: The boy caught butterflies in his net.

desc: A philosophy is a way to think about truth and life.
exam: My philosophy is “live and let live.”

desc: A pot is a deep, round metal container used for cooking.
exam: Don’t touch the pot on the stove. It’s hot.

desc: A seed is the hard part of a plant or fruit that trees grow from.
exam: I planted the seed in the dirt hoping that it would grow into a tree.

desc: When something is sharp, it has a thin edge that cuts things easily.
exam: That knife is very sharp. Be careful not to hurt yourself.

desc: A sort of something is a type of it.
exam: What sort of instrument do you want to learn to play?

desc: To subtract means to take something away.
exam: We learned how to subtract numbers from each other in class.

desc: When something is tight, it is fixed or fastened firmly in place.
exam: The knots were too tight to untie.

desc: If something is virtual, then it is very close to being true or accurate.
exam: Because he’s popular, Joe is the virtual leader of the group.

desc: To weigh something means to see how heavy it is.
exam: The little dog weighed exactly 3kgs.

desc: To whisper means to say very quietly.
exam: We have to whisper in the library so people can focus on reading.

desc: If ideas are abstract, they are based on general ways of thinking.
exam: The idea of beauty is abstract and changes over time.

desc: If something is annual, it happens once a year.
exam: The only time I see my aunts and uncles is at our annual family picnic.

desc: Clay is a type of heavy, wet soil used to make pots.
exam: She made a bowl out of the clay.

desc: Cloth is material used to make clothes.
exam: His shirt is made of a very soft type of cloth.

desc: A curtain is a cloth hung over a window or used to divide a room.
exam: She opened the curtains to let light into the room.

desc: To deserve is to be worthy of something as a result of one’s actions.
exam: The dog deserved a bone for behaving very well.

desc: Feathers are the things covering birds’ bodies.
exam: That bird has orange feathers on its chest.

desc: If land is fertile, it is able to produce good crops and plants.
exam: The farmer grew many vegetables in the fertile soil.

desc: A flood is an event in which water covers an area which is usually dry.
exam: After three days of rain, there was a flood in the city.

desc: Furniture is the things used in a house such as tables and chairs.
exam: His living room only had a few simple pieces of furniture.

desc: A grave is the place where a dead person is buried.
exam: We visit our grandfather’s grave each year.

desc: If something is ideal, it is the best that it can possibly be.
exam: This house is an ideal place for my family. It has everything we need.

desc: Intelligence is the ability to learn and understand things.
exam: Because of his high intelligence, he finished school early.

desc: If something happens nowadays, it happens at the present time.
exam: In the past people walked everywhere. Nowadays, they use cars.

desc: To obtain is to get something you want or need.
exam: After I passed the test, I obtained my driver’s license.

desc: When something is religious, it has to do with religion.
exam: The holy man spoke about religious topics.

desc: When something is romantic, it has to do with love.
exam: The young couple went to see a romantic movie.

desc: A shell is a hard covering that protects the body of some sea creatures.
exam: There were many pretty shells on the beach.

desc: A shore is the edge of a large body of water.
exam: All of the boats were floating near the shore.

desc: A wheel is a round thing on a vehicle that turns when it moves.
exam: A car has four wheels.

desc: To appeal to someone is to be interesting or attractive to them.
exam: Sleeping all day appeals to me, but I have to go to school.

desc: To assume something is to think that it is true, even with no proof.
exam: I assume you are both familiar with this plan.

desc: To borrow something is to take it and then give it back later.
exam: Can I borrow a pencil to use today? I’ll give it back to you tomorrow.

desc: A client is a person or business that pays another to do a service.
exam: She has many clients who enjoy coming to her salon.

desc: The downtown is the center of most cities.
exam: The downtown is filled with many tall buildings.

desc: If something is dull, it is not exciting.
exam: The movie was very dull. I fell asleep watching it.

desc: To embarrass someone is to make them feel ashamed or foolish.
exam: He was embarrassed when he couldn’t remember her name.

desc: A fare is an amount of money paid to use a bus, train, or taxi.
exam: Since he is a senior, my grandfather pays a low fare for the bus.

desc: Former describes something that used to be but is not any more.
exam: The hotel, a former castle, was built over 200 years ago.

desc: A formula is a set mathematical way or method of solving a problem.
exam: I learned a new formula that may help us with our problem.

desc: To found a company or organization means to start it.
exam: The pilgrims founded one of the first colonies in the United States.

desc: To invest means to use money in a way that will bring a profit later.
exam: I invested money in a new building that should bring me a profit.

desc: A loan is the act of lending something, usually money.
exam: I got a loan from the bank.

desc: If something is practical, it is useful in normal life.
exam: Learning English is practical; you can use it in many places.

desc: A quarter is 25 cents.
exam: He paid a quarter for the candy.

desc: A salary is how much money a person makes at his or her job.
exam: He got a new job with a better salary.

desc: A scholarship is money given to one so they can go to school.
exam: I got a scholarship to help me pay for university.

desc: If something is temporary, it exists for a short time.
exam: This car is only temporary; I’ll get a new one soon.

desc: A treasure is a collection of valuable things, especially jewels or gold.
exam: They became very rich when they found the buried treasure.

desc: To urge someone is to try very hard to get them to do something.
exam: He urged them to believe his story.
